channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.title: ã€TC39 advances numerous proposals at latest meetingã€‘TC39åœ¨æœ€æ–°ä¼šè®®ä¸Šæå‡ºäº†è®¸å¤šå»ºè®®
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹739 â€” June 6, 2025

Read on the Web

ğŸ–Šï¸ I was meant to be traveling this week. My plans changed, but Iâ€™d planned for a shorter issue, so enjoy the bitesize take! Back to full service next week.Â :-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

âš¡Â Announcing Rolldown-Vite â€” Rolldown is a fast Rust-based JavaScript bundler designed to eventually be used by the equally fast Vite build tool - now itâ€™s a reality. Itâ€™s a drop-in replacement too, and early adopters are reporting huge build time reductions. Try it now before it becomes theÂ default.

Evan You

TC39 Advances Several Proposals at Latest Meeting â€” Coverage of what happened at last weekâ€™s meeting of the folks working on the ECMAScript spec whose decisions influence what becomes everyday JavaScript (eventually). Array.fromAsync, Error.isError, and explicit resource management all move to stageÂ 4, among otherÂ things.

Sarah Gooding

CodeRabbitâ€™s Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf â€” Code Rabbit brings AI code reviews to VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf. Get line-by-line reviews, one-click fixes & codebase-aware feedback - all free in your IDE. Seamlessly integrates with git workflows. Install the extension & startÂ reviewing!

CodeRabbit sponsor

WebStatus.dev: Now with More Data, Deeper Insights, and a Clearer Path to Baseline â€” Google's Web Platform Status site lets us query and track various web platform features and the browsers that support them. Itâ€™s had a big updateÂ recently.

Kadir Topal (Google)

IN BRIEF:

  • The React Native team has frozen the legacy architecture codebase in order to focus solely on the New Architecture goingÂ forward.

  • SQLite-JS is an interesting SQLite extension that adds the ability to write custom SQLite functions using JavaScript.

  • The State of CSS 2025 survey is now open toÂ take.

RELEASES:

  • Babel 8 Beta â€“ Follows on two years from the alpha, but "All the breaking changes we were planning to include in Babel 8 are done".

  • ESLint v9.28.0 â€“ The popular linter adds more TypeScript syntax support to coreÂ rules.

  • AngularFire 20.0 â€“ Integrate Firebase into Angular apps. Now supporting the new AngularÂ 20 released lastÂ week.

  • Vitest 3.2, Astro 5.9, Ionic 8.6, Prisma 6.9.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

A JavaScript Developer's Guide to Go â€” Go is a popular, fast language most commonly used for backend work, and this is a good primer targeted at JavaScript developers keen to learn more aboutÂ it.

Prateek Surana

ğŸ’¡ If you get into Go, we also publish Go Weekly, a newsletter just like JavaScript Weekly but for Go developersÂ :-)

document.currentScript is More Useful Than I Thought â€” â€œEvery so often, I stumble across a well-established JavaScript API in the browser that I probably shouldâ€™ve known about yearsÂ ago.â€

Alex MacArthur

â–¶Â Â Talks from Svelte Summit Spring 2025 â€” The Svelte team recently promised to release the talk videos from its recent Svelte Summit event, and there are already 12 to enjoy here. â–¶ï¸Â What Svelte Promises by Rich Harris, Svelteâ€™s creator, is the obvious entryÂ point.

Svelte Society

ğŸ’¡ If videos aren't your thing, the Svelte team has also published a monthly update of what's new in Svelte, as of JuneÂ 2025.

ğŸ“„ Write More Reliable JavaScript with Optional Chaining â€“ It might?.be?.a?.good?.idea Matt Smith

ğŸ“„ How Imports Work in React Server Components Dan Abramov

ğŸ“„ Intercepting Network Requests in Chrome Extensions rxliuli

ğŸ“„ The Ingredients of a Productive Monorepo Sean Gillespie

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

php-node: A Way to Seamlessly Bring PHP to Node.js â€” A neat idea, even if you donâ€™t like PHP. Itâ€™s a native module for Node that lets you run PHP apps within the Node environment. Why? For migrating legacy apps, building hybrid PHP/JS apps, or Node apps that simply need to call out to PHP for some reason (WordPress, maybe, as shownÂ here).

Matteo Collina et al.

Learn How to Monetize Your SaaS with Clerk Billing â€” Clerk Billing makes SaaS subscriptions easy â€” no custom UI, no webhooks. Learn how to set it up in thisÂ guide.

Clerk sponsor

Storybook 9: The UI Component Workshop â€” The popular one-stop tool for working on, and testing, frontend UI components gets a big update in terms of testing. Storybook Test offers interaction, visual, and accessibility testing, complete with a â€˜watch modeâ€™ for testing whenever you save, whether youâ€™re working with React, Svelte, Next.js, React Native, andÂ more.

Michael Shilman

ğŸ–ï¸Â Beachpatrol: A CLI Tool to Automate Your Everyday Web Browser â€” A higher level way to use Playwright on macOS or Linux to control a regular non-headless browser instance. Itâ€™s essentially an approach where you still want a visible browser you can use in a normal way but with added automationÂ possibilities.

Sebastian Carlos

  • Starry Night 3.8 â€“ GitHub-like syntax highlighting.

  • ngx-vflow 1.9 â€“ Add node-based interfaces to AngularÂ apps.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€A timeline of JavaScript's historyã€‘JavaScriptå†å²çš„æ—¶é—´è¡¨
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹737 â€” May 23, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Brief History of JavaScript â€” JavaScript (originally named LiveScript) turns thirty years old this year and the Deno team has put together a fantastic timeline-based tour of how much things have progressed from its first appearance in Netscape Navigator, through offshoots like JScript, standardization, and the introduction of Node.js, all the way through to the modernÂ day.

The Deno Team

2x-40x Faster Docker Builds with Blacksmith â€” With a one-line code change, Blacksmith can make your Docker builds incremental by mounting your Docker layer cache into your GitHub Actions runner. Blacksmith is used by 600+ companies like Ashby, Clerk, andÂ Mintlify.

Blacksmith sponsor

âš¡Â Announcing TypeScript Native Previews â€” Earlier this year, Anders Hejlsberg teased a 10x faster TypeScript through efforts being made to port the TypeScript compiler to Go, enabling it to be compiled and run natively, as well as take advantage of more concurrency. The good news is you can now give it a.. go forÂ yourself.

Microsoft

â–¶Â Â An Introduction to JavaScript Frameworks â€” The creator of SolidJS has put together a tight 11-minute video boiling down the different approaches taken by React, Angular, Vue, Svelte, and Solid. Dense, but a great way to get a lay of theÂ land.

Ryan Carniato

IN BRIEF:

  • Ryan Dahl responds to recent community chatter about the state of the Deno project in 'Reports of Deno's Demise Have Been Greatly Exaggerated'.

  • Guess the Output is a fun multi-choice JavaScript quiz to put your knowledge to the test. Each answer is explained as youÂ go.

  • A look at the agenda for next week's TC39 meeting, including the proposals up forÂ discussion.

  • React Router now has preview support for React Server Components.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v24.1.0 (Current) and v22.16.0 (LTS)

  • Bun v1.2.14 â€“ The fast JS runtime &Â toolkit.

  • Slonik v48 â€“ Node.js Postgres client with runtime & build time typeÂ safety.

  • Zod v4, Astro 5.8, ESLint v9.27.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

â–¶Â Â What's New in Angular â€” Two members of the Angular team presented a session at this weekâ€™s Google I/O event on the latest updates to the Angular framework in anticipation of the eventual release of Angular 20 nextÂ Thursday.

Chasanoff and Thompson (Google)

ESLint v9.0: A Retrospective â€” Itâ€™s been a year since ESLint v9.0 landed as the first major release in a few years. It enabled the new flat-config system by default and the rollout didnâ€™t go as smoothly as hoped. This retrospective breaks down the full story and shares the lessonsÂ learned.

Nicholas C. Zakas

Getting Started with Clerk Billing â€” Learn how to build a complete billing experience with Clerk and Stripe, no custom UI or webhooksÂ required.

Clerk sponsor

Six Ways Slack, Notion, and VS Code Improved Electron App Performance â€” An experienced Electron app developer shares a guide to Electron performance optimization and how to get the most out of yourÂ apps.

Amila Welihinda

ğŸ“„ How the at() Method Makes Array Indexing Easier Matt Smith

ğŸ“„ Styling Console Text in Node.js Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ Authenticating JavaScript WebSockets Steven Waterman

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Defuddle: Extract the Main Content from Web Pages â€” Strips extraneous clutter from HTML in order to leave only the primary content for you to format or use as you wish. Essentially a modern implementation of the ideas behind Mozillaâ€™s Readability. Thereâ€™s an online demo if you want to give it aÂ try.

Steph Ango

snapDOM: Captures DOM Nodes as Images â€” A fast and accurate DOM-to-image capture mechanism to capture any HTML element as a scalable SVG image, preserving styles, fonts, background images, etc.

ZumerLab

AI-Powered Code Reviews for JavaScript Teams â€” CodeRabbit helps you ship cleaner JavaScript by reviewing every PR with AI that understands yourÂ codebase.

CodeRabbit sponsor

ForesightJS: Predictive Mouse Intent Library â€” An interesting concept, with the entire page acting as a demo of sorts. The idea is to decrease latency by prefetching data or pages as soon as you think a user might be heading in that direction. Your mileage may vary and itâ€™s less useful for touchÂ devices.

ForesightJS, Inc.

Astra: A New JavaScript-to-EXE Compiler for Windows â€” Boasts â€œa new approach to compilingâ€ JavaScript applications for a single executable experience on Windows only (forÂ now).

QwertyCodeQC

Crosspost: A JS Utility for Posting Across Multiple Social Networks â€” Currently supports eight different services including Bluesky, X, Mastodon, andÂ LinkedIn.

Nicholas C. Zakas

Rockpack 6.0: An Alternative React App Starter â€” A tool aiming to get React project setup time as low as possible, complete with server side rendering support, bundling, linting and testing. v6.0 updates everything for React 19. GitHubÂ repo.

Alex Sergey

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ Calendar Link 2.10.0 â€“ Generate event links for popular calendarÂ services.

  • octokit.js 5.0 â€“ 'All-batteries-included' GitHub SDK for JavaScript.

  • image-type 6.0 â€“ Detect the image type of a Buffer/Uint8Array.

  • Peggy 5.0 â€“ Parser generator forÂ JavaScript.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Build a professional design system in less than a day, using Hope AI, new model by Bit.Cloud. Enjoy reusable UI components ready forÂ import.

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere..

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • Google's I/O event took place this week and â–¶ï¸Â its 'developer keynote' was a highlight, particularly when Addy Osmani showed off some of the latest Chrome DevTools fun (starting at about 30 minutes in).

  • Microsoft has unveiled a new Postgres extension for VS Code that brings IntelliSense completion to SQL, GitHub Copilot integration, a visual way to explore your schemas, andÂ more.

  • ğŸ¤– Anthropic has unveiled its new Claude 4 models. The Claude family of LLMs are quite heavily used by modern coding agents, as well as Claude's own now-generally-available Claude Code tool.

  • The Glitch platform, a popular way to build and host Node-backed webapps, is shutting down its app hosting functionality â€“ it seems uncertain quite what Glitch will or won't be afterÂ July.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

åœ¨ç½‘ä¸Šé˜…è¯»

ğŸ“–articles

â–¶ - Angularå›¢é˜Ÿçš„ä¸¤åæˆå‘˜åœ¨æœ¬å‘¨çš„Google I/Oæ´»åŠ¨ä¸Šä»‹ç»äº†Angular Frameworkçš„æœ€æ–°æ›´æ–°ï¼Œä»¥æœŸæœ€ç»ˆå‘å¸ƒAngular 20ä¸‹å‘¨å››ã€‚

Chasanoffå’ŒThompsonï¼ˆGoogleï¼‰

Nicholas C. Zakas

- å­¦ä¹ å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨æ–‡å‘˜å’Œæ¡çº¹å»ºç«‹å®Œæ•´çš„è®¡è´¹ä½“éªŒï¼Œæ— éœ€è‡ªå®šä¹‰UIæˆ–Webhooksã€‚

åº—å‘˜

<è·¨åº¦æ ·å¼=â€œ font-weightï¼š600; font-sizeï¼š1.1em; colorï¼šï¼ƒ000;â€œ> - ç»éªŒä¸°å¯Œçš„ç”µå­åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå¼€å‘äººå‘˜åˆ†äº«äº†ç”µå­æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–æŒ‡å—ä»¥åŠå¦‚ä½•ä»åº”ç”¨ä¸­è·å¾—æœ€å¤§æ”¶ç›Šã€‚

Amila Welihinda

ğŸ“„ğŸ“„

ğŸ“„

è¿™æ˜¯æœ¬å‘¨æ›´å¹¿æ³›çš„ç”Ÿæ€ç³»ç»Ÿä¸­çš„ä¸€äº›ä¸œè¥¿ï¼š

  • Googleçš„â–¶qus'å¼€å‘äººå‘˜ä¸»é¢˜æ¼”è®²'æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªäº®ç‚¹ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯å½“Addy Osmaniå±•ç¤ºä¸€äº›æœ€æ–°çš„Chrome DevTools Fun æ—¶ï¼ˆä»å¤§çº¦30åˆ†é’Ÿå¼€å§‹ï¼‰ã€‚

  • Microsoftå·²å…¬å¸ƒ

  • ğŸ¤–æ‹ŸäººåŒ–å…·æœ‰Claude Code tool.

  • glitch å¹³å°æ˜¯ä¸€ç§æ„å»ºå’Œä¸»æœºèŠ‚ç‚¹æ”¯æŒçš„ç½‘ç»œåº”ç”¨çš„æµè¡Œæ–¹å¼ï¼Œæ˜¯

item.title: ã€Everybody's gone lintin'ã€‘æ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½èµ°äº†
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹740 â€” June 13, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of React and the Community in 2025 â€” React continues to be a major dependency in the JavaScript world but recent innovations have led to much discussion about how it should move forward. Redux maintainer Mark Erikson gives an overview of Reactâ€™s development over time, what led to some of its innovations, and dispels some â€˜FUD and confusionâ€™ about where it'sÂ headed.

Mark Erikson

ğŸ’¡ While we cover the biggest React stories in JavaScript Weekly, React Status is our weekly newsletter dedicated to React, so check it out for moreÂ depth.

How Notion Cut Typing Latency By 15% â€” Stop guessing why your web app is slow. Paletteâ€™s production JS profiler tells you why, down to the line of code. Get started for freeÂ today.

Palette sponsor

Announcing Oxlint 1.0: The Super Fast Linter â€” First appearing just 18 months ago, Oxlint has made an impact by being an incredibly fast Rust-powered linter for JavaScript and TypeScript, boasting a 50~100x performance improvement over ESLint while still having support for hundreds of its rules. Now, itâ€™s goneÂ stable.

Boshen Chen and Cameron Clark

pnpm 10.12 Introduces an Experimental Global Virtual Store â€” pnpm has long been prized for its speed and efficiency over npm. v10.12 takes things further introducing a â€˜global virtual storeâ€™ that node_modules symlinks to, enabling projects to share dependencies without them being installed numerousÂ times.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

IN BRIEF:

  • Surfin' Safari? Apple's WWDC25 event this week saw numerous developments that aren't 'liquid glass' related, including a look at what's new in Safari 26 (beta) including support for pattern modifiers in RegExp objects.

  • A writeup of a vulnerability found in OpenPGP.js.

  • Matteo Collina gives us a public service announcement around the end-of-life of some recent Node.js versions and some tips on upgrading to v22.

  • Gleam is an easy to read/write language targeting both Erlang and JS runtimes. The big news is that Gleam compiled to JS is now 30%Â faster.

RELEASES:

  • H3 v2 BetaÂ â€“ Cross-runtime Web standards focused HTTP serverÂ framework.

  • Node.js v24.2 (Current) â€“ import.meta.main is a new boolean value available in ES modules that tells you if the current module was the entry point of the current process.

  • Visual Studio Code May 2025 â€“ Big enhancements to MCP support, but VS Code extensions can now also use ESÂ modules.

  • Deno 2.3.6, Rollup v4.43, Jasmine 5.8, Vue DevTools v7 for Firefox

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Suppressions of Suppressions â€” If youâ€™re using a linter to keep your code clean, you may have silenced rules that feel too strict or irrelevant. But those suppressions can bury serious bugs. Dan Abramov argues for adding a rule to forbid disabling your most criticalÂ checks.

Dan Abramov

How JavaScript Was Written Back in the Day â€” Itâ€™s not the earliest JavaScript, but Trevor looks back at code written in the 2006-2015 pre-ES6Â era.

Trevor I. Lasn

The Only Test Runner Fully Integrated with AI Agents â€” Wallaby upgrades your AI agent to an expert debugging partner with runtime data, coverage, execution paths, runtime dependencies and real-timeÂ insights.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Native Hot Module Reloading in Node via Module Hooks â€” A clever use of module hooks to implement â€˜hot moduleâ€™ functionality natively and efficiently.

Immaculata

ğŸ“º Don't Use JSON.parse & JSON.stringify â€“ Jack points out some of these functionsâ€™ shortcomings and possibleÂ workarounds. Jack Herrington

ğŸ“„ How ESLint Language Plugins Enhance DSL Usability Nicholas C. Zakas

ğŸ“„ Things to Avoid in JavaScript â€“ A reminder of someÂ basics. Suren Enfiajyan

ğŸ“„ Angular 20 Might Seem Boring â€” 6 Reasons Itâ€™s Not Yan Sun

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

npmgraph: A Tool to Visualize npm Module Dependencies â€” Give this Web-based tool one or more npm package names (or even your package.json file) and you can see a visualization of the dependency graphs for those packages, including where they intersect. Packages can be colored by various criteria (such as number of maintainers) and you can download SVGs of theÂ graphs.

Kieffer, Brigante, et al.

Jest 30: Faster, Leaner, and Better JS Testing â€” A â€˜noticeably fasterâ€™ release of this popular testing framework, adding improved ESM and TypeScript support, performance improvements and more. Upgrade docsÂ here.

Zaytsev & Nakazawa

Sync Clerk User Data to Supabase in Real Time with Webhooks â€” Stop polling and start syncing. This guide shows how to stream Clerk user updates into Supabase withÂ ease.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸŠÂ Orange ORM: An Active Record ORM for JavaScript and TypeScript â€” A powerful ORM for Node, Bun and Deno, supporting both TypeScript and JavaScript, and both CommonJS and ESM. It follows an Active Record-style querying approach, is well documented, and certainly worth a look if working with most of the popular SQLÂ databases.

Lars-Erik Roald

Vue Equipment: A Toolkit for Nuxt and Vue.js â€” A collection of ready-to-use plugins and composables for building modern web apps with both Vue and Nuxt. ExplainedÂ here.

Magic as a Service

ğŸŒ“Â DarkModeJS 2.0: A Utility Package for Managing Dark Mode â€” Uses the matchMedia API and the prefers-color-scheme media query to fire functions whenever a user is in dark mode (or changes theÂ mode).

Assortment

ğŸ•¹ï¸Â Odyc.js: A JS Library for Pixel Games/Stories â€” Has a bit of a 8-bit Game Boy Color vibe to it. You can create games, and try some examples, in this onlineÂ playground.

Charles Cailleteau

  • ğŸ¤– Midscene.js 0.18 â€“ Let AI and JavaScript be your browserÂ operator.

  • Acorn 8.15 â€“ Small, fast, JavaScript-based JavaScriptÂ parser.

  • xo 1.1 â€“ Opinionated but configurable ESLint wrapper.

  • Mocha 11.6 â€“ Test framework for Node &Â browsers.

  • JsBarcode 3.12 â€“ Barcode generationÂ library.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

"Change is just a merge away" - âœ¨ Automate code reviews with InfinitcodeÂ AI:Â TryÂ freeÂ now.

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ‘€Â  Fun, fun, fun..

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • The billionth repo on GitHub (be warned, it has a mildly NSFW name) has just been created to muchÂ celebration.

  • Shopify explains its work on making import maps easier to use, including work on shims, the HTML spec, and encouraging browser developers to implementÂ improvements.

  • GitHub's remote MCP server is now in public preview. It enables AI agents and tools to access live GitHub context and work with various concepts like issues and pullÂ requests.

  • You may recall the TypeScript team is porting the TypeScript compiler to Go to take advantage of both native compilation speedups and Go's concurrency features. John Reilly and Ashley Claymore explain why Go is a 'pragmatic choice' for this project.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

é¢œè‰²ï¼šï¼ƒ3366aa;â€œ>åœ¨ç½‘ä¸Šé˜…è¯»

ğŸ“–æ–‡ç« å’Œè§†é¢‘

- å¦‚æœæ‚¨ä½¿ç”¨è¡¬é‡Œä¿æŒä»£ç æ¸…æ´ï¼Œåˆ™å¯èƒ½ä¼šæ²‰é»˜çš„è§„åˆ™è¿‡äºä¸¥æ ¼æˆ–æ— å…³ç´§è¦ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯è¿™äº›æŠ‘åˆ¶ä¼šæ©åŸ‹ä¸¥é‡çš„è™«å­ã€‚ä¸¹Â·é˜¿å¸ƒæ‹‰è«å¤«ï¼ˆDan Abramovï¼‰ä¸»å¼ æ·»åŠ è§„åˆ™ç¦æ­¢ç¦æ­¢æ‚¨æœ€å…³é”®çš„æ£€æŸ¥ã€‚

Dan Abramov

- ä¸æ˜¯æœ€æ—©çš„JavaScriptï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯Trevorå›é¡¾äº†2006- 2015å¹´Pre-ES6æ—¶ä»£æ‰€å†™çš„ä»£ç ã€‚

trevor I. lasn

- è¢‹é¼ å°†æ‚¨çš„AIä»£ç†å‡çº§åˆ°å…·æœ‰è¿è¡Œæ—¶æ•°æ®ï¼Œè¦†ç›–èŒƒå›´ï¼Œæ‰§è¡Œè·¯å¾„ï¼Œè¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¾èµ–æ€§å’Œå®æ—¶è§è§£çš„ä¸“å®¶è°ƒè¯•åˆä½œä¼™ä¼´ã€‚

wallabyå›¢é˜Ÿ

- å·§å¦™åœ°ä½¿ç”¨æ¨¡å—æŒ‚é’©æ¥å®ç°â€œçƒ­æ¨¡å—â€åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå’Œæœ‰æ•ˆã€‚

immaculata

ğŸ“º Jack Herrington

ğŸ“„ Suren Enfiajyan

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹738 â€” May 30, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Wake Up, Remix! Everything's Changing.. â€” Big news from the Remix camp this week. About a year ago, Remix and React Router merged together reflecting their shared goals and code, but now itâ€™s all change again. React Router is now basically what Remix originally intended to be, and so â€˜Remixâ€™ is rebooting as a model-first, low-dependency, Web API-centric full-stack framework built on Preact. Itâ€™ll no longer be a 'React framework' perÂ se.

Michael Jackson and Ryan Florence

ğŸ•’Â The Upcoming Temporal API and What Problems It Will Solve â€” The Temporal API has been cooking for many years now as a new way to work with dates and times in JavaScript. Itâ€™s just been enabled in Firefox 139 by default and sure to come to more runtimes ASAP. Hereâ€™s why it matters and what itÂ offers.

Suren Enfiajyan

CodeRabbitâ€™s Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf â€” Code Rabbit brings AI code reviews to VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf. Get line-by-line reviews, one-click fixes & codebase-aware feedback - all free in your IDE. Seamlessly integrates with git workflows. Install the extension & startÂ reviewing!

CodeRabbit sponsor

Announcing Angular v20 â€” A big release for the Google backed framework where a lot of the more recent experimental features (like signals and incremental hydration) have received a lot of polish and been promoted as stable. There are new experimental APIs too, including resource streaming and httpResource for making HTTP requests with a signal-based reactiveÂ API.

Minko Gechev

ğŸ’¡ While the official release post (above) is packed with content, you might appreciate this brief magic-themed roundup of what's new in AngularÂ 20.

IN BRIEF:

  • Matteo Collina has unveiled php-node, a way to run PHP apps within the same process as Node.js. Run WordPress with a Next.js frontend?Â Sure.

  • TC39's 108th meeting is currently taking place with many proposals being advanced, such as Seeded Pseudo-Random Numbers moving to stage 2 and Error.isError moving to stageÂ 4.

  • The OpenJS Foundation is now a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) for over 40 popular JavaScript projects it hosts, including ESLint, Express, andÂ Electron.

  • Node's technical steering committee has decided against instituting an official bounty program.

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.2.15 â€“ Gains a bun audit tool for performing security audits of projectÂ dependencies.

  • Ink 6.0 â€“ Use React to build CLIÂ apps. Now supporting ReactÂ 19.

  • Docusaurus v3.8 â€“ Popular docs-oriented static site generator.

  • Ember 6.4, JSPM 4.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

Why Are 2025/05/28 and 2025-05-28 Different Days in JavaScript? â€” An interesting â€˜Watâ€™-like moment in just the first few lines of this post, which Brandon decided to dig into andÂ explain.

Brandon Dong

â–¶Â Â Modern Performance Debugging in Chrome DevTools â€” Paul shares a look at the reimagined Chrome DevTools Performance panel, showing off new features, how they work, and how to use them to make performanceÂ gains.

Paul Irish

Build an LMS SaaS App from Scratch â€” Learn to build a production-ready AI SaaS using Next.js with auth, billing, and an AI voiceÂ agent.

Clerk sponsor

React, Visualized: A Visual Exploration of React Concepts â€” The creators of a React course have updated their popular visual explainer of numerous core React concepts to cover React 19 and features like actions, transitions, and Server ComponentsÂ too.

Tyler McGinnis et al.

â–¶Â Â The 3 Ways JavaScript Frameworks Render the DOM â€” The creator of the SolidJS framework looks at the different approaches frameworks take to render what they produce. A good look under the hood that isnâ€™t too complex. (16Â minutes.)

Ryan Carniato

Build a Blog with Angular in Under 30 Minutes Using Analog â€” Analog is a meta-framework for Angular (think along the lines of Next.js orÂ Nuxt).

Peter Mbanugo

Your React Meta-Framework Feels Broken, Here's Why â€” â€œSometimes youâ€™ve got to burn it all down, start from ash, and rebuild from first principles. This is what we did withÂ RedwoodSDK.â€

Redwood Team

ğŸ“„ No Server, No Database: Smarter Related Posts in Astro with Transformers.js Alexander Opalic

ğŸ“„ A Thought on JavaScript 'Proof of Work' Anti-Scraper Systems Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Multithreading in JavaScript with Web Workers Badmus Kola

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Svelte Flow 1.0: Create Node-Based UIs and Diagrams in Svelte â€” From the creators of the similar React Flow comes a customizable Svelte component for building node-based editors and interactive diagrams. WantÂ examples?

webkid GmbH

Cap: A Lightweight, Modern Open Source CAPTCHA Alternative â€” This solution boasts a method called â€œproof-of-workâ€ which attempts to make automated CAPTCHA solving more expensive. It uses a Web Component and you can try out a few demos here. GitHubÂ repo.

Cap

Enterprise Requirements Slowing You Down? Thereâ€™s a Better Way â€” WorkOS lets devs ship SSO, SCIM, audit logs & moreâ€”fast. Trusted by industry-leading teams like OpenAI, Vercel &Â Plaid.

WorkOS sponsor

Google Gen AI SDK for TypeScript and JavaScript v1 â€” Why let Python developers have all the fun? Now you can harness the full power of Googleâ€™s Gemini API (and Vertex platform) from Node.jsÂ too.

Google

ReactJust: Server Components Without a Framework â€” If, for some reason, you donâ€™t want to adopt a full-scale framework like Next.js or React Router to use or experiment with RSCs, this â€˜vanilla RSCâ€™ approach could be ofÂ interest.

almadoro

  • NeutralinoJS 6.1 â€“ Lightweight cross-platform desktop appÂ framework.

  • Linkify 4.3 â€“ Turn links, hashtags, and mentions in text to HTMLÂ links.

  • image-type 6.0 â€“ Detect the image type of a Buffer/Uint8Array.

  • Faker 9.8 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • file-type 21.0 â€“ Detect the file type of a file, stream, orÂ data.

  • Mineflayer 4.29 â€“ Create Minecraft bots inÂ JavaScript.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

How Notionâ€™s engineering team tackled viral user growth to run PostgreSQL at scale on Amazon RDS withÂ pganalyze.

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere..

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • The annual Stack Overflow Developer Survey is back for a fifteenthÂ year.

  • A Minecraft-style building experience in pure CSS â€“ no JavaScript atÂ all!

  • Simon Willison writes about how GitHub Issues works really well as a personal notebook for taking notes, linking them together, and generally organizing whatever sort of information you want. It doesn't have to just be for codeÂ projects.

  • I just discovered that Matthias Bynens, who you might know for his work on everything V8, ECMAScript specs, and more, keeps a repo of the 'smallest possible syntactically valid files' in many differentÂ formats.

  • Did you know you can style alt text like any other text on WebÂ pages?
